args:
The apostles meet with Basileus and hear how
Origa sought Satan's power in order to resist
the Progenitor, and also how he was fueled
by his own quest for vengeance. But though
his tone is one of despair and resignation,
Pinon pushes him to fight on.

(We hurried north of the city in an attempt
to stop the foreign army from marching on
Satan, but we were too lateâ€”they had
already entered the miasma.)
What are you fools screaming about?!\nDon't let a little mist make you...\nHrrrk?! AAAAAAAAAAH!
We're too late! The miasma's corruption\nis turning them against each other!
We don't have enough holy water on hand\nto purify them all. Prioritize the uninjured!
We'll take care of that! The rest of you\nwork on getting people out of here!
Thank you... You saved my life...
Nnngh... The miasma has me lightheaded.\nI need to get out before... Wait!
This device is meant to shield the wearer\nagainst the miasma's effects, but the mist\nis too concentrated here for it to be of use.
But I still I have to reach her. I must...\nHnngh? AAAAAAAH!
I see you're still alive, Basileus.
Easy, there. It's not like you to panic.
We managed to get about half of the army\nout safely. But the rest of them...
There's nothing you or anyone could have\ndone back there. Also, there's something\nI noticed.
That miasma surrounding Satan is\nspreadingâ€”or maybe it's more appropriate\nto say that he's the one spreading it.
It's possible it will reach all the way to the\nevacuation site even before he reawakens.
Then we need to get the survivors\naboard the Gran Fiore.
It's time to get clear of this place.
The Watch can direct people as needed.
We're happy to help as wellâ€”but first,\nI need to hear what Basileus has to say. \nHe should wake up any minute now.
Will you permit me to join you? I am\nmost eager to hear what became of\nAuspex Origa.
Yep. It's us. And it's time for you to tell\nus what's really going on here.
Sounds like Loki had you and Origa\nfooled the whole time. Is that right?
I am also given to understand the Auspex\nsought Satan's power so she might fight\nback against the Progenitor?
You're the Auspex from the south, right?
Strictly speaking, I am the Auspex from\nthe south who crossed into this particular\nexistence from another world.
Another world? ...Hmm, I suppose since\nOriga had the power to connect with other\nworlds, it makes sense you could too.

Still, I hear the south worshipped their
new Auspex from the moment they
discovered her, which means your path
was nothing like hers.

When the Ilian Church of Grams chooses
a new Auspex, they gather promising
candidates from across the land. Origa,
for example, was from an orphanage.

They make them all undergo training, and
the one whose talents blossom brightest
becomes Auspexâ€”and it's not the kind
of offer the girl is able to turn down.

Those whose power fails to bloom are
disposed of. And even if they do bloom,
only one can be chosen. Sometimes they
even make the candidates kill each other.
From the moment the church leadership\nsaw her potential, Origa had one choice:\nbecome the Auspex or perish.
But the Auspex's power brought with it\na terrible revelation.
She beheld the Progenitor sealed away in\nanother world and was given a taste of\nthe new reality he intended to create.
She must have projected her mind to\nthat world and made contact with the\nProgenitor.
In the Progenitor's vision of the perfect\nworld, all is predetermined. Every life,\nevery death, every moment.
However miserable the fate dealt to you at\nbirth, your efforts can earn you no chance\nof redemption. It is a world devoid of pity.

To a woman like Origa, who had fought a
cruel fate and emerged victorious through
unadulterated will, it was a thing she
could not countenance.
She didn't attempt to consult others about\nher concerns and rally a united effort?

To the Northern Church, the Auspex is an
oracle whose augury serves their political
needs. An ornamental tool trotted out to
justify their rule.
An Auspex who glimpses the end and\npanics the masses undermines that,\nand would be named a heretic.
The same holds for her role as Pope.\nAny act which threatens the powers that\nbe is grounds for immediate removal.
So she felt she had to keep quiet.
Yet she still searched for a means to fight\nback against the Progenitorâ€”and that\nsearch brought her in contact with Loki.
He claimed Satan's power was sufficient\nto return all to nothingness, but it could\nalso be harnessed with the Auspex's mana.
So she found hope in Satan's rebirth,\nnever knowing it for a false promise.

She steeled herself to become his vessel
and drafted a plan together with Loki,
after which the two of them chose
me to help them execute it.

At the time, I knew only that one of the
Northern Church's cardinals put my
entire village to the torch, but Origa told
me that Graht was the one responsible.
After revealing this, she pressed me to\njoin her scheme to resurrect Satan.
In exchange, she promised to kill Graht\nin the process.
So you accepted despite knowing the plan\ncame with a body count way bigger than\none crooked cardinal.
My vengeance was everything.\nNothing beyond that mattered.

Once I agreed, Loki brought a false plan to
Graht, claiming Origa would be sacrificed
and I would be the vessel while he held
Satan's reins as the new pope.

It galled me to play at being his loyal dog,
but the view at the end was worth it.
When I think of him dying as he did...
Oh, but it makes me smile.
I think I know how Origa felt. If I had to\nlive my whole life as a weakling with no\ncontrol over my destiny, it would crush me.

I can empathize with your pain, Basileus.
But that pain didn't give you the right to
take still more lives. By doing so, you were
no better than Graht himself.

People were slaughtered in Paradise.
Hundreds fell as sacrifices here.
And they all had families and homes
equally precious to your own.

Origa agreed with you. Though she was
determined to act, the thought of the
sacrifices haunted her to the very end.
But me? I was different.
Even before I became an apostle,\nI sacrificed others for my own goals\nwithout hesitation.
So yes, I killed people. I betrayed you all.\nIf you want to hate me for it, go ahead.\nIndeed, I almost welcome it.
Hang on there, pal. Exactly where do you\nthink you're going?
I will face Satan and strip him of the\nShard, no matter what it takes.
So you mean to enter the same miasma\nthat nearly killed you earlier? Madness!
I was slowed down by those small fry the\nlast time, but I don't intend to make the\nsame mistake again.
It doesn't matter if the path is strewn with\nroses and a red carpet. You can't push\nthrough that miasma and you know it.
My Sigil is severed, which means I am\nalready a dead man walking. There's no\ntime to look for another way.
Uh...did she really just slap him?

That clear your head a bit? Good!
So here's the deal: Time is short as hell,
and we all need to figure out how best to
use what little of it we have left.
Stay calm, focus on the task at hand,\nand exercise clear judgment at all times.\nYou taught me that, remember?
I must be a lost cause if I'm getting\nlectures on professionalism from you...
When Origa fell to Satan's corruption,\nyou became desperate. I saw it.
Yours wasn't the face of a man\nwho was only in it for revenge.
Instead, it looked like a man who'd set out\nfor revenge, but somewhere along the way\ndeveloped certain...feelings.
...And if I said your wild assumption\nwas correct?
Look, I'm as tempted as you are to dive\nheadlong into that miasma. I want to reach\nout and offer her my hand.
But as much as it galls me, I'm not free\nto indulge in that kind of self-destruction\nright now BECAUSE I love her.
...Possibility yet remains.\nI must retrieve what is needed before\nthe demons take notice...
